messages.subject: my stuff
messages.msgSnippet: gang, I am in the process of photograhing my accumulation of Japanese arts . Basically the menuki, fuchi/kashira, kozuka folder are done ( some not in the
messages.messageBody:
gang,

I am in the process of photograhing my accumulation of Japanese arts .

Basically the menuki, fuchi/kashira, kozuka folder are done ( some
not in the exact folders as they are mounted on swords ).

tsuba folder is 3/4 done but in the next few days should be
finished........

paintings ( hawks and other subjects ).......barely scratch the
surface , as are the nihonto, ceramic and ukiyo-e folders. These
will take months....... but do check in periodically, you never know
what you'll get next ( quoting Forest G. here ).

Hopefully more members will do the same........... better than
searching through the muddy waters of e-bay and see what's availble
locally here in US of A.

Please klick.........
http://www.esnips.com/profile/54ee848f-5436-411d-abf1-e6ba8060dc94

milt

taste test the old-timers talk about.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Blokes - could this be Tosa Myochin?? Barry Thomas. ... From: Richard Turner  To:  Sent: Wednesday,
messages.messageBody:
Blokes - could this be Tosa Myochin??

Barry Thomas.


----- Original Message -----
From: "Richard Turner" <ikkanshi@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, November 23, 2005 6:59 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] tsuba question


http://www.nihonto-club.net/upload/joyimages/2440.jpg

Hello group, I have a small Ji Sukashi tsuba I think is Edo Owari
school. It has long running
tokettsu in the mimi and looks well forged.

My question is in regards to the theme. I see to geese at 12 and 6
oclock, what the the items at 2, 4, 8 and 1
0 oclock, are they plant fonds ?.

Do the two sections that come in from the mimi to the hitsu ana mean
anything ?.

Thank you for your time.

cheers

Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, ... None, other than the brass that they inlaid on iron plates. ... None. ... Supposedly the Akao worked in iron when the were in Echizen and only
messages.messageBody:
Rich,

>on Iron guards, did the Heianjo group make many soft metal works ?

None, other than the brass that they inlaid on iron plates.

>or the Akasaka group for that matter ?.

None.

>Also, I thought the Echizen Akao group only worked in Iron ?

Supposedly the Akao worked in iron when the were in Echizen and only started in copper alloys when they moved to Edo. I haven't made a study of that myself so I can't comment on the exclusivity, but there are Edo Akao works in shakudo.

Jim


Just trying to remember whilst watching the computer do it's thing.

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The Seijo were one of the sidelines.  There were 7 generations of the Seijo family spanning the Edo period.  They made quite a few iron tsuba (compared
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The Seijo were one of the sidelines. There were 7 generations of the Seijo family spanning the Edo period. They made quite a few iron tsuba (compared to other Goto lines) with designs and techniques following machibori fashions. I doubt that your guard is their work, though.

Jim


How about Goto Seijo school?

Rich S


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: ... it looks a lot like Bushu Ito work.  I can t think of any mainline iron tsuba.  Can anyone?  The mainline Goto did not make a lot of tsuba, even in their
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:
> Rich,
> The iron tsuba are confined to the Goto sideline families. Some of
it looks a lot like Bushu Ito work. I can't think of any mainline
iron tsuba. Can anyone? The mainline Goto did not make a lot of
tsuba, even in their usual materials. The earliest generations didn't
make any tsuba, or at least none survive.

How about Goto Seijo school?

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The iron tsuba are confined to the Goto sideline families.  Some of it looks a lot like Bushu Ito work.  I can t think of any mainline iron tsuba.  Can
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The iron tsuba are confined to the Goto sideline families. Some of it looks a lot like Bushu Ito work. I can't think of any mainline iron tsuba. Can anyone? The mainline Goto did not make a lot of tsuba, even in their usual materials. The earliest generations didn't make any tsuba, or at least none survive.

Jim



There are some similarities with the Goto piece cited;
especially the treatment of the hitsuana. I somehow never
think Goto when dealing with iron tsuba :-)

Rich S

messages.subject: tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: What school? Both the Shoami and Umetada used the basket weave design a lot, but the forging and surface texture don t quite fit either IMHO. Big tsuba, 96 mm
messages.messageBody:
What school? Both the Shoami and Umetada used the basket weave design
a lot, but the forging and surface texture don't quite fit either
IMHO. Big tsuba, 96 mm with nice brown patina.
It has been suggested Ko-Shoami, but again the surface texture
and forging are what I think of as Ko-Shoami.

Any thoughts appreciated.

http://home.earthlink.net/~ttstein/tsuba.jpg

Thanks
Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Wisteria have compound leaves that look somewhat like sumac or ash.  A google image search on wisteria will turn up lots of examples.  Your two guards
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
Wisteria have compound leaves that look somewhat like sumac or ash. A google image search on wisteria will turn up lots of examples. Your two guards are probably kiri motif. The one in the eBay link is the same type, but probably younger yet, although it looks like it may have been cleaned a bit enthusiastically.

I hadn't thought of it before, but the sukashi openings in this one combined with the hammering of the plate reminds me of Shoami Shigenobu's plate work. I don't know if there is any relationship there. I can't think of any heianjo-type brass inlay work by Shigenobu.

Jim
>
> Jim,
> more wisteria with leaves like that.................
>
> http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?
> ViewItem&item=2242762231&category=43338&sspagename=STRK%3AMEBWN%
> 3AIT&rd=1
>
> this one is Hieanjo zogan too ?
>
> Milt



Jim et al,

Tom brought up the point on another list that it is kiri
(paulawnia).
The leaves do look like that. The wisteria has pointy leaves, ja ?

Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 5/15/2004 5:47:35 PM Central Daylight Time, jggilbert@EARTHLINK.NET writes: They re grouped under Heianjo, but they are a consistent
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 5/15/2004 5:47:35 PM Central Daylight Time,
jggilbert@... writes:
They're grouped under Heianjo, but they are a consistent sub-style. They
have those deeply hammered plates almost like Tembo work, and the brass inlay
motifs vary but don't seem to directly relate to the forming of the plate.
Ron, Rich, Jim et al,

Thank you all for your opinions, greatly appreciated !!

By the way, the brass inlays are positioned on the " flip side " of the
hammered " depressions ".

milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, They re grouped under Heianjo, but they are a consistent sub-style.  They have those deeply hammered plates almost like Tembo work, and the brass inlay
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
They're grouped under Heianjo, but they are a consistent sub-style. They have those deeply hammered plates almost like Tembo work, and the brass inlay motifs vary but don't seem to directly relate to the forming of the plate. The shape of the kogai ana is also very consistent within this type. I'm not aware of any signed examples that would give a clue as to how they might relate to the other types of brass inlay guards lumped together under Heianjo zogan. They seem to date to Momoyama to early Edo. Yours is on the later end of the range.

I've never seen a wisteria with leaves like that.

Jim

messages.msgSnippet: Milt, The hitsuana are also very different, as are the shape of the seppa dai and the overall outline.  Not a particularly harmonious daisho to my eyes.  Mid

Milt,
The hitsuana are also very different, as are the shape of the seppa dai and the overall outline. Not a particularly harmonious daisho to my eyes. Mid Edo?

Jim

Hi ye all,
I uploaded a pic of a sukashi tsuba to the list photo album inside album
labelled " Milt's ".
Also kinly check the tsuba listed as tsuba 1 in Sho-shin's web site
<A HREF="http://www.sho-shin.com/TSUBA1.htm">http://www.sho-shin.com/TSUBA1.htm</A>

As you all can see, the design and style are very similar but there are
subtle difference...e.g. the album's tsuba has no outline along the sukashi.,
the mimi seems to be more rounded.

Based on the photo..........
questions......
1. are the tsuba of the same school ?
2. approximate time period ? Early Edo ? earlier even ? Late Edo ?
3. Assuming one tsuba is larger than the other, can these two be " daisho "
?

Danke in advance.................

Milt
